0.0: מתני' המביא גט ממדינת הים AN AGENT BRINGS A DIVORCE DOCUMENT [GET] FROM OVERSEAS — All land outside of Eretz Yisrael is called overseas except for Babel, as it says further (Gittin 6a).
0.1: צריך THE AGENT MUST — The agent bringing the get must state the formula, and the reason is explained in the Gemara. The husband sent this agent in order to deliver the divorce document.

1.0: רקם וחגר REKEM AND ḤEGER — Translation of "Kadeish and Bared," as they were translated "between Rekem and Ḥeger" (Genesis 16:14).
1.1: אפילו מכפר לודים EVEN FROM THE VILLAGE OF LUDIM TO LOD — Which [the village of Ludim] is outside of Eretz Yisrael.
1.2: ללוד TO LOD — Which is close to the village of Ludim, but is in Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara explains this argument [between the Tanna Kamma and Rabban Gamliel]

1.0: This is a leniency: This is a question.

14.1: And this stumbling block - meaning, so began the discourse on scripture, it is written "this stumbling block [ruin] under your hand" regarding the men of Jerusalem for whom Torah had ceased, and they were asking their friends "you have a mantle, be our ruler, and this ruin should be under your hand", that is to say, these things that are opaque like your mantle, you that are an expert on them, tell us [what to do] and be a ruler. And this stumbling block are the words of Torah, that a person does not have a firm standing on their truth unless he stumbles on them, to teach mistakes and be humiliated by them, and then one pays attention and understands. Under your hand they are - even I stumbled in my teaching and retracted [what I said].

15.0: Fears: Is concerned to see the outcome; such that if I do this no misfortune should arise from it.
15.1: A shaft from a chariot (rispak): The siding of a women's chariot, which is called, rituga, in the language of Ashkenaz (German). And it is like a type of wagon. For we say in [the chapter entitled] Oto veEt Beno (Chullin 79a), "If you bring me mules [attached] to a wagon (rispak)."
15.2: Kamtza and bar Kamtza: Such was the name of two Jews.

16.0: Whose friend was Kamtza: His friend's name was Kamtza.

0.0: He said to him, "No": [I will not] leave you alone.
0.1: He said to him: He (Bar Kamtza) [said], "I will give you money for half of your feast."

1.1: An offering: A sacrifice to offer on top of the altar. Since we establish, "Any man (ish ish)" (Leviticus 22:18), to include the idolaters who may vow to bring vow offerings and gift offerings like a Jew (Chullin 13b).

2.0: On the overhanging lip: The upper lip.
2.1: For them, it is only a blemish to sacrifice to the Higher realm on their altar, one missing a limb. Dokin is teile (in Old French); as in, "spread out like a dok" (Isaiah 40:22).

3.0: They will say, "One who makes a blemish on sacrificial animals is to be killed": Such that they will reason that he was killed because he placed a blemish in [a sacrifice] and transgressed on account of, "no blemish shall be in it" (Leviticus 22:21).

4.0: His humility: His tolerance, since he tolerated this one and did not kill him.

5.0: He shot an arrow to the east: To engage in divination, when he was close to Jerusalem.

6.0: That child: We do not follow the version: He stuttered in his speech.
6.1: By the hand of My people Israel: Through My people Israel.
6.2: And to clean His hands: To wipe his hands.

7.0: Nakdah: Pierced, [like] the usage, "we pierce the mountains" (Eruvin 58a). He had the sun pierce for him - it shone for his sake, in Tractate Taanit (20a).
7.2: Dragged along on blankets and seats: As he would only walk on fine wool.
7.3: There are those who say: His name was Ben Tzizit. So why was he called HaKesat? Because kissato, his chair, was found among the nobles of Rome when he went to Rome to greet Caesar.

8.0: They had: These three rich men [had] wheat, barley, wine and wood to sustain all the people of the city for twenty-one years.

9.0: Zealots (or Ruffians): Empty people eager for war.
9.1: The Sages said to them: To these zealots.
9.2: You will not be successful: To win.
9.4: They burned down these ambarei: These storehouses of produce and wood [were burned] so that they would fight.

11.1: And she died: Due to her delicateness.

12.0: Figs: From those that Rabbi Tzakok left over [after] he sucked its liquid. And she found it and ate it out of her hunger. But she tasted of the smell of Rabbi Tzadok's sickness that had entered the fig and died from her delicateness.
12.2: From the outside: Because he was skinny.
12.3: When he would eat: When he finished his fasts and wanted to feed himself.
12.4: They would bring him figs: Dried figs. Since he was not able to swallow something thick, he would suck its liquid and throw out the figs.

14.1: He sent to him: Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai [sent the message], "Come to me in secret."
14.2: He said to him: Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai [spoke].
14.3: Until when will you do this: As you have not allowed us to make peace.
14.4: Show me a method for me: That they will let me leave the city.

15.0: Pretend to be sick: Act as if you are sick; put out a rumor that you are sick.
15.1: To ask about you: As if you were dying.
15.2: Bring something putrid: Something that smells, such as an animal corpse.
15.3: And place it near you: And lay it in your bed with you, so that they will say, "He is dead and already smells."
15.4: And have your students enter: They should go under the legs of your bier to carry [it]; and they should not allow others to carry [it]. As they know that a living person is lighter than a dead person.

16.1: To pierce him with spears, lest he was tricking [them].
16.3: They will say: The Romans [will say] about you, that they even stab their teachers.
16.4: To push him: Maybe he would yell.

17.0: Because I am not a king: And you mocked me.

0.0: In truth, you are a king: You will be a king in the future.
0.1: And their mighty one shall be of themselves, and their ruler shall proceed from the midst of them: Hence a mighty one is a ruler.
0.2: And Lebanon [means] the Temple: Since it whitens (malbin) the iniquities of Israel.

1.0: Wrapped around it: Stuck and determined about it.
1.1: Wouldn’t they break the barrel: In order for the snake to leave. So too should you have destroyed the city wall and burned it with fire in order to send away those zealots from within it.
1.2: And we leave the barrel: This is what we foresaw: Perhaps we could [defeat] them and expel them from it, so that the city would survive and we could make peace with you.

2.1: It would not come off: As his limbs thickened from the joy of the announcement.

3.0: And a broken spirit dries the bones: And when your spirit is broken because of your enemy, your bone will dry.

4.0: Give me Yavneh: That you should not destroy it and you should not kill its Sages.
4.1: And the dynasty of Rabban Gamliel: The family of the Nassi. That you should not kill them, so that you not extinguish the rulership of the House of David.
4.2: And physicians: Give me physicians from your people, so that they will heal Rabbi Tzakok. As he was not able to ingest food, because his intestines had shrunken from his fasts.

5.1: That much: For he would not [agree] to leaving Jerusalem for him. And it would occur that he would not have done even a small salvation. Hence he asked this from him, so that there be a small salvation.

6.0: Water of bran: Water in which bran was soaked.
6.1: Water of sipuka: Coarse bran and flour was mixed into [water].

8.0: Your enemies roar in the midst of Your meeting place: In the house in which You meet [with others].
8.1: They have set up their own signs for signs: They said that their sign is this sign of blood: Whose is it if we did not kill himself?
8.2: Himself: An epithet for the One above.

10.0: A type of gargutni: A large basket into which we pour out wine from the press into the pit and call, coledoir [in Old French].
10.1: But those that had done so were forgotten in the city: This great might that you see.

11.0: Items that had been buried: Hidden treasures from the money of Israel.

12.1: Sisera: The Kishon River dragged [his army] away.

13.0: An entrance: A mouth to bring in food.
13.1: An exit: To excrete through the anus.

14.1: It was silent: That gnat [was silent] from picking because of the sound of the hammer.
14.2: Since it became accustomed, it became accustomed: From when the gnat get used to the sound of the hammer, it recognized it and did not leave its picking.

0.0: With that which he decreed against himself: They burn [him] and sprinkle [his] ashes.

1.0: In boiling semen: It is measure for measure, since the people began to whore after the daughters of Moav from his counsel (to Moav).

3.0: As the Master said: In Eruvin (21b). And he learned it from, "and much study (lahag) is a weariness of the flesh (Kohelet 12:12)": Whoever mocks (malig) much will be sentenced to weariness of the flesh; and this verse is written about the words of the Scribes (the rabbis) [as the first part of it is understood as], "My son, be careful to fulfill the words of the Scribes even more than the words of the Torah."
3.1: The prophets of the nations that worship idolatry: Bilaam - to whom the Divine Presence was revealed, yet he spoke evilly.

7.0: In separate scrolls - When each portion was told to Moses, he wrote it down and, after 40 years when all the portions were completed, he attached them with sinews and bound them.

4.0: Words that are not given over orally may not be transcribed -From here you learn that the Talmud may not be written, only because the Torah would be forgotten.
With the dead of Israel - Not in the Jewish graves, rather, deal with them if they are found amongst Jewish corpses.
